conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the suitcase and use the conditions for equilibrium to find the angle θ and the coefficient of friction μ.
Identify the forces acting on the suitcase: weight (W = mg = 150 N), normal force (N), tension in the pull (T), and frictional force (F_f = μN).
Resolve the pull into horizontal and vertical components: horizontal component is T cos θ, vertical component is T sin θ.
Set up the equations for equilibrium: vertical equilibrium (N + T sin θ = W) and horizontal equilibrium (T cos θ = μN).
Substitute N from the vertical equilibrium equation into the horizontal equilibrium equation: T cos θ = μ(W - T sin θ).
Rearrange to solve for T: T = μW / (cos θ + μ sin θ).
Use the given minimum pull T = 90 N to find θ and μ: 90 = μ × 150 / (cos θ + μ sin θ).
Simplify to get: 5μ/3 = cos θ + μ sin θ.
Use the condition for the minimum value of the pull: F_min = W sin θ / (cos θ + μ sin θ).
For the minimum force to be 90 N: 90 = 150 sin θ / (cos θ + μ sin θ).
Rearrange to solve for μ: 90 cos θ = sin θ (150 - 90 μ).
Since tan θ = sin θ / cos θ, substitute sin θ = tan θ cos θ into the equation: 90 = tan θ (150 - 90 μ).
Substitute θ = 37° (sin 37° = 0.6, cos 37° = 0.8) into the equation: 5μ/3 = 0.8 + μ × 0.6.
The coefficient of friction μ is 0.75 and the angle θ is 37°.
Final answers are μ = 0.75 and θ = 37°.
